segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 I'm here. When I'm done, I'm going to go out to that room. There's going to be a table
where I'm going to sit, and I'll chat and answer questions for as long as you guys want
until I get really tired. And according to my schedule, it's a little bit early, so I
don't want to wait, because a couple of people are filing. What is my talk going to be on?
I don't know yet. The CAA guy might be more interesting than me. These guys think I'm
a CAA. I'll see if there's someone else. You can go talk to that person. She will be over
in a hundred seconds. It's mainstream music, I know. Is this punk industrial or goth techno?
This is grunge. I can't tell the difference. Actually, it doesn't sound half bad.
You want to spot feds? No. There are probably some here. Some are wearing dark glasses indoors.
That can't bode well. We'll start. I think this is a good time to start. Hi, I'm Bruce
and I'll take questions. Anybody? This person asked about Kerberos and Microsoft. It's a
vaguely interesting topic. We're not really quite sure what's going on. Kerberos is an
old authentication protocol designed at MIT in the early 80s. It allows people to log
into computers more robust than username and password. And it has sort of bumbled along
for the past decade and a half, used in various applications. There are free implementations.
It shows up in products once in a while. Microsoft added support for Kerberos in Windows just
recently, I think Windows 2000. Kerberos also became an IETF standard, an Internet Standard
for Authentication. It's sort of a competitor to a PKI-like standard. It might not be a
security thing. When Microsoft put it in Windows 2000, they made it different than the IETF
standard. And one of the questions you ask is, did they do this just to annoy compatibility,
which is sort of something they generally do? Or was there some other reason? When you
make changes in the security standard, you have to worry about, does it affect security?
And there was lots of talk of why they made this change and whether it affected security.
After writing that piece in Cryptogram, I have not looked at it, so I don't have any
good answers. I haven't seen anybody else say, this is bad for security reasons. People
have said this is bad for compatibility reasons, but not for security reasons.
There's a good question. AES. Who doesn't know about AES? Does anybody need a refresher
course on AES? I'll give them two minutes. In the mid-70s, the National Bureau of Standards
wanted to produce a standard encryption algorithm. And they sent out in the Federal Register,
which is this little book of government contract solicitations, candidate algorithms that would
become a standard. And they got a whole lot of garbage. They submitted another request
for standards. I think this is like 1976. And they got a whole lot of garbage, and something
from IBM called Lucifer. And history happened, and Lucifer became DES, and that became the
government standard algorithm for the past 20 or so years. In 1990, let me see if I get
these years right. In 1996, NIS, which is what the NBS became, the National Institute
of Standards and Technology, not the National Institute of Technology and Standards, which
would be NITS, but they were NIS, decided that they needed to replace DES. They made
a dollar short, but they were right. So they did the exact same thing. They had a couple
of conferences in, I think, 96 and early 97, where we would all get together and say what
do you think we should do? And we would come up with a standard. And these were all open,
anybody could show up. And lots of people did, and some had useful opinions, a lot of
them didn't. In spring of 98, early 97, they asked for submissions for AES. The rules of
the game were 128-bit block cipher, faster than DES, key lengths of 128 bits, 192 bits,
236 bits. That's why things like IDEA and Blowfish and others you might be used to were
not submitted, they didn't meet the criteria. Submissions were due, sorry, I have the years
wrong, because submissions were due like summer of 97, maybe like June 15th or something.
21 algorithms were submitted, 15 of which met the submission criteria. One of the criteria
was you had to have working code. So if you produced an algorithm with not working code,
you were tossed out. Working code in C, someone submitted their working code in Pascal.
There were 15 submissions. These came from all over the world. These came from the United
States, from Canada, from Japan, Korea, Costa Rica, Australia, Belgium, England, I'm missing
places, all over the place. From academia, from industry. And this is the AES competition.
Counterpain submitted an algorithm called Two Fish, hence the shirt, don't tell Seuss, which
we submitted along with the other 14. And it's been kind of neat, you sort of think of it as the
big cryptographic demolition derby. We all put our algorithms into the ring and we beat on each
other and the last one left standing wins. In August of 97 was the first AES conference
where we all got to present our algorithms. Now this is actually kind of an interesting story.
Over the past months, after submission before the conference, people would publicize their
submissions. And we had seen all of them except this one submission called Magenta from Germany.
And Magenta was presented at the AES, it was kept secret until the workshop, presented at the
workshop, and broken during the question session. When a good cryptographer starts a question
with, can you please put up slide 14 again, nothing good can ever come of it.
So the first round of demolition derby happened between 97 and 98, I'm getting the years wrong,
between 98 and 99. No, 97, 99, I'm screwing this up. 97 was the submission deadline.
No, 98 was the submission deadline, because in 99, in April, was the second candidate conference
where we all presented papers attacking each other, talking about efficiency on different platforms.
And there were lots of good papers, some algorithms were broken, four odd definitions were broken,
and then this went into a cave and they chose five semifinalists. And they chose, if I can do this in
alphabetical order, Ringdahl, sorry, RC6, Ringdahl, Mars, Serpent, and Two Fish. They chose five.
RSA submission, IBM submission, the submission from the academics of Belgium, the submission from
Ross Anderson in the UK, Ellie Beam in Israel, and Lars Knudsen in Norway, and the submission from us.
And then we had the third AES candidate conference in New York in March, which was basically the
second round of demolition derby. And lots of papers were presented, and what NIST is doing now
is they have crawled back into their cave, and they will choose one winner. And we don't know which
one it is. They want to get it chosen by August, crypto is in August, and they'd like to have it
chosen by then. We don't know if they will. I think our chances are okay. I believe it's down to three of
them, Ringdahl, Serpent, and Two Fish. Ringdahl is the fast one but risky. Serpent is the slow and
conservative and we're the compromise. So depending on how I feel in the morning, I think our chances
are better or worse. Now, this will never be as ubiquitous as DES. If you think back to the 1970s,
there were no alternatives to encryption algorithms. DES was all anyone ever had. So everyone used
DES. Now we have triple DES, we have IDEA, we have Blowfish, we have RC5, RC4, lots of algorithms,
IDEA, I think I said that, CAS, lots of algorithms are seeing wide use. So DES, while it will be used,
will not become nearly as ubiquitous. But it's been great fun. I've had the most fun possible as a
block cipher cryptographer. Actually designing a cipher, we wrote a book about the design and analysis,
going through the real work, not just spending two weeks and saying I did this, but spending a good year
designing and breaking and designing and coming up with a submission. Then watching other people attack
it and see what they found that we missed. Us attacking other submissions. It's really been a ball.
This is enormously fun. So that's where that is. Who asked that question? All right, I have things to
throw to you guys. It's supposed to be a good tape. It's a demo tape from somebody. And I want to get
to him. If I can get to him, that would be cool. There's a question over there.
Yesterday, one of the government panelists stated that there are a number of products, algorithms,
that are generally thought to be untrackable, that are in fact haven't been tracked by the government.
Do you have any speculation as to what those products are?
Okay, let's talk about this question in two parts. The first question is what algorithms have been
cracked. The second is what products have been broken. And they're very different questions.
Now, I believe in when you start looking at products out there, those that don't use standard
algorithms often use really horrible things. And we see that all the time. We saw that in all the
digital cellular algorithms. We saw that in some of the DVD stuff. We saw that firewire.
This is example after example of company producing proprietary algorithm and it being broken.
Now, a lot of these we never actually break because we either never see them, we're too busy.
I get stuff sent to me all the time. This isn't a product. Will you look at it? And I usually say I'm too
busy. If the government cares, they will look at it. So they're likely to have broken a lot of the
dorky algorithms that people use that haven't gotten the kind of peer review that you expect.
The larger and more interesting question is what products have been broken. And this is something
I've come to in years of analyzing cryptographic systems. What I'll find is no matter how bad the
cryptography is and how lousy the algorithms are, something else is worse. It's almost never the math.
We saw that with the DVDs, a perfect example of that. There was this mediocre algorithm with bad
key length, but it didn't matter, you can break the system anyway. Even if the cryptography was
perfect, it would still be a lousy system. And you find that in a lot of software packages, things break
not by beating on the math, but by looking around the edges. And to a first approximation, the math
almost doesn't matter. The analogy I like to use is it's like putting a large pole in the ground, hoping
the enemy runs right into it, instead of building a wall. And we can argue whether the pole should be a
mile tall or a mile point two tall, but in the end that doesn't matter, because the enemy is going to go
right around it. So for someone like a government, or even anybody who's doing analysis of commercial
products, whether they're firewalls or VPNs, I believe they're all breakable. It's just a matter of finding
where the overflow bug is, where the bad random number generator is, where the programming mistake is.
That's where the mistakes are. And we've really been sold a false security, and I'm probably guilty of
selling this, because here I am writing applied cryptography, saying things like the mathematics will
protect you. Well, that's actually not true, the mathematics doesn't. The mathematics is actually really
good, but there's so much around it that undermines it. In a lot of ways, the mathematics doesn't matter.
Who wants this? You want one of these? If you don't want it, there's somebody else.
I'll take the air first.
There was a few years ago you theorized that public key cryptography was at least 10 or 15 years behind.
People like to say that it's NSA, but if you put this snapshot today, how far off do you think it is?
I don't remember saying that three years ago, but okay.
The general question is, let's take the NSA as compared to the academic world.
It's an interesting speculative question. Where are we compared to them?
You can look at this theoretically. The NSA is a one-way lens.
They take everything we do, and they give us nothing they do.
By definition, they're ahead. Even if they know one more thing, they're ahead, because they're not telling us that one thing.
More interestingly, think about what they're doing. Their job is really bread and butter, breaking production ciphers.
Stuff that is used in militaries, by governments, they break them.
And that's what they have a lot of resources on.
At the academic community, we don't do that with the same single-mindedness as they do.
And they've also been doing it a lot longer.
Is that my phone or someone else's phone?
So the odds are that they are better at breaking block and stream ciphers.
Just because they're better at it. They've been doing it longer.
They have more expertise. They have a bigger body of knowledge.
But we actually don't.
What's a break in academia is not a break in the NSA.
I could produce a break that has a 2 to 100th complexity.
And we can say this AES candidate is broken.
But as far as the NSA is concerned, I've done nothing, because they can't read traffic.
All they care about is, can I read traffic in something resembling real-time?
So I believe they are ahead in that.
In the esoteric protocols, authentication protocols, commerce protocols, sharing of content,
academia, I think, is very far ahead, because that's a business thing.
That's not something the government needs.
There's a lot more research done in business.
A lot more things are fielded. A lot more things are tested.
So I believe we're ahead of that.
In public-key cryptography, either there's parity or they know some things we don't.
It's clear, if you look at the sorts of research they were funding in the 70s,
that there are some areas we should go into that we're not.
Whether that was fruitful, I don't know.
It's very hard to speculate about public-key cryptography,
because those are really number theory questions,
and not little techniques and tricks to break things.
So I'm not sure where we are compared to the government in public-key.
You know, 10 to 15 years might be a reasonable number.
We might come back here 15 years from now and find we're no further ahead than they are,
than we are today.
So maybe 15 years of research could yield no results.
We don't even know if there are results out there for us to find.
This is one of those questions you just speculate on for a while.
Did you get one of these?
Let's go from this side of the room. Let's go right in the back.
I'm going to talk a little bit, because I actually don't want to talk about the company,
because that's kind of chilling to these guys.
Basically, what we're doing now is I'm doing internet burglar alarm services.
The idea being that, from what I just said, all of these products have flaws and problems,
and if you don't have real-time monitoring of your security,
you're not going to do any good.
It's like a bank saying, our bank vault is so good, we don't need a burglar alarm.
That never happens in the real world.
So we're trying to build an internet burglar alarm
for companies that need to monitor their networks and don't have the expertise.
I'd love to talk about it, but I don't want to do it here,
because you guys don't want to hear me talk about my company.
All right, that side of the room fails.
How about over there?
What do you see here?
Would you understand the submissions to AES were?
Relatively free.
Oh God, fame and glory.
This came up during the AES process.
In the beginning, some people said you can't restrict it to free algorithms,
because no one will submit.
As it turns out, we got some extremely high-quality submissions.
Many groups, including IBM and RSA Data Security,
numbers of universities, companies, NTT in Japan,
submitted and gave away their algorithm,
which probably was many years of work.
Why do we do it?
One, because it's way fun.
And I assume companies did it for fame and glory.
I mean, getting chosen for AES would be cool.
But really, if you like doing ciphers, this is what you do.
And if you're going to make it proprietary, no one will use it.
We sort of learn that again and again.
And I believe everybody who's good at cipher design understands that.
In order for a cipher to be widely used, analyzed, trusted,
it has to be free and available.
So NIST, I think, made the right choice,
as evidenced by the fact that they got 15 high-quality submissions.
And they didn't get stuff tossed off by kids.
They got real things with work on them.
And that was kind of neat.
Oh, okay, you have orange hair. That counts for something.
Well, first, I'm glad you're hearing my favorite speaker at DEF CON.
Well, thank you.
You're my favorite audience member.
I have two questions.
One is, maybe it's a naive question on my part,
but is it more difficult to decrypt, cumulatively,
a message that's been wrapped in separate protocols?
For example, if I took an image and then did a PGP,
and then say, okay, this is separate.
Number two is, can you describe how, if they found a new crime,
that could be used to develop an algorithm?
God, if I could invent a new algorithm on the fly,
I would write a paper, so I really can't.
How important is a new crime?
A new crime is a bad word.
How important is a new way of doing public key?
Probably not very.
This is one of our problems in cryptography.
Pretty much all of our public key algorithms are based on the same piece of mathematics.
The difficulty of factoring large numbers or the discrete log problem,
which is basically the same.
The same solutions apply to both.
And nobody actually knows that factoring is hard,
for any reasonable definition of the word hard.
It could be quite possible that in a few years,
somebody invents a way to factor numbers easily,
and we have no public key cryptography anymore.
We're dropping down some really icky, ugly things.
It's a bad single point of failure.
I don't want to lose a lot of sleep over it,
but weird things have happened.
We had Fermat's Last Theorem proved,
and that was proved using elliptic curves and modular forms.
Forget what that means.
Someone found a bridge between two very diverse areas of mathematics,
and was able to pull the math from one to solve a problem in the other,
in a very new and surprising way.
Now, one of those two areas is strong in cryptography.
So it's certainly possible that there are things going to happen.
So a new way of doing public key cryptography that had nothing to do with prime numbers
would be useful. I'd like to see that.
I'd like to see it now, so in six years we might actually even trust it.
But I don't know how likely that is to happen.
Public key sees me based on this one hard problem, and that's what you get.
Back there. Talk loud, though.
I don't like NTRU. NTRU is dumb.
Is that a rebuttal?
Only if it's not a rebuttal.
I'll take the one in the back first.
These are devices to break public key systems.
Let's talk about them.
Twinkle is just an optical computer that's optimized for factoring.
There's really interesting engineering there.
There's not a lot of science there.
Quantum computing is more interesting.
A few years ago, someone, I think Peter Shore, invented the notion of a quantum computer.
The idea would be we don't need this silly Von Neumann architecture.
We can do stuff with quantum mechanics and waves and build a computer.
This is all done on paper.
No one has actually built anything at this point.
Then the question came up, what the hell is a quantum computer good for?
Well, surprise, the first algorithm invented that can be used in a quantum computer
was to factor large numbers very fast.
So break RSA.
The second thing they figured out a quantum computer was useful for
is breaking discrete log algorithms.
So basically a quantum computer is, almost by definition,
a public key cryptography breaker.
If you could actually build it, which you can't.
More research has happened.
There is practical work building quantum computers going on right now.
I know at Sandia they have a quantum computer that can factor the number 15.
So anybody using 4-bit RSA should worry.
In theory, in my lifetime, your lifetime, somebody's lifetime,
a quantum computer will be built.
There's no real reason why it won't.
It's a simple matter of engineering.
The math is done.
We don't know how it will work, what it will look like,
but this is interesting.
In general, a quantum computer will speed up any key search by a factor of square root,
which means for any symmetric algorithm it cuts the key size in half.
So if right now a 64-bit key is vulnerable,
under a quantum computer a 128-bit key would be vulnerable.
Now a 128-bit key will not be broken in anything resembling human lifetimes,
or species lifetimes.
So a 256-bit key would be secure in a quantum environment to the same degree.
So it's not devastating.
We're not going to lose everything if a quantum computer is invented.
But it would be a big deal.
And thankfully people are working on it.
And that's good.
I said I'd take this person next.
No, I'll take him.
I keep forgetting about these.
Oh, I didn't even go close.
Where do you see PKI going and when do you see it getting there?
Open ended question.
I wrote about this already.
And if you go to my website, you can read about it.
How'd I do?
Actually, you know, seriously, a lot of this, I do a monthly newsletter called Cryptogram,
which if you don't subscribe, who subscribes? Tell the people next to you, subscribe. Thanks.
And in there, what I do is, I answer questions like that, so I don't have to answer them
ever again. And over the months, I do lots of essays on these sorts of topics. And I
did a long essay with another colleague called Carl Ellison on PKI, on really trying to bring
down the hype and talk about the realities of using PKI and what it means security-wise.
It's a long essay. It's a good essay. It asks a lot of very hard questions and then attempts
to answer them. And in the end, it isn't very satisfying, which is cool. And I do urge people
to read, if they're interested in PKI, especially if companies are rushing to PKI because it's
the buzzword du jour, which it is. So rather than spending an hour, I could do it in an
hour. It's worth reading. My opinion hasn't changed in what I wrote, which I guess is
the important thing I should tell you. I will take a question from this area. Oh, the one
there. What? Give him a tape. That's true. I'm sorry. I'm going to hurt somebody. Okay.
You. Yes, you. No, because they know they're better cryptographers. Cryptography is a weird
field because it's by nature antagonistic. You invent something and someone else breaks
it. And then you break their break. So all cryptographers have thick skins. You have
to. You publish and your stuff is shot down. And even the best cryptographers, Adi Shamir,
wrote a paper, I think maybe it's 5, 10 years ago, on a public key scheme. And it was broken
in the days before the conference. So he gets up on stage in front of everybody and says,
hi, I'd like to discuss a very interesting failure. You get used to that. And that's
what cryptography is. I always feel my expertise is less in new cryptography and more in explaining
cryptography to other people. Do I still care about privacy? Yes. I'm not sure how that
fit in. No, I don't see a lot of jealousy. Of course, maybe I'm just not paying attention.
Oh, back there. Is there any way to protect against keyboard logging? This is a good general
question. We'll answer the general question. This is one of those breaking crypto around
the world. How would we break PGP? An easy way to break PGP is to put in a keyboard logger.
Not only get the messages, you get their passphrases. And the question is, how do you prevent against
this? It's really hard. If you have a general purpose computer, you can't. If you had a
closed bot, you'd never put a keyboard logger in an ATM machine because you can't get inside
it. But you can always put a keyboard logger or a screen capture device or any of those
things onto a general purpose PC. If you don't have secure hardware, you're not going
to prevent against those sorts of attacks against the I.O. because the I.O. is inherently
insecure. If you're a trusted insider, you can do lots of things. This is the problem
you see with content protection. The DVD content protection scheme worked okay as long as the
algorithm and decoder was in a VCR, in a closed box that you couldn't get to. As soon as they
made a software player, you can reverse engineer it, you can do whatever you want. As soon
as you put a security device onto a general purpose computer, you can circumvent it. You
can't stop that. The content people are still figuring this out. And eventually they're
going to get it. It can take a while. And security is also the same problem. I cannot
prevent. Someone at home, I'm here, they could be putting a keyboard logger on my computer
or home computer. I can't stop them. I can't detect it. It's just a big hole in security.
You have to trust the platform. You see that problem again with the Digital Signature Act.
How do you know? This is something I did in my book. I would say to sign a message, the
signer computes message to the D mod N. That's complete bullshit. I have never computed M
to the D mod N in my life. My computer computes M to the D mod N. And it is an article of
faith that when I click sign, that my computer does that. I have no clue what my computer
does when I click sign. I don't. It could not sign. It could send a copy of the plain
text to you. It could sign a completely different message. I'm trusting what it's telling me
on the screen. I don't know what's going on inside the processor. This is a big security
problem and something we don't know how to solve. But general purpose hardware has a
lot of security risks.
This is not quantum cryptography. This is about 15 years old. A basic quantum physics
lesson. In quantum mechanics, when you observe a particle, you change its state by definition.
Naively, that's a cool way to detect eavesdropping. If someone eavesdrops, they observe the particle
and necessarily change its state. As it turns out, you can build a cryptographic mechanism
based on this property. You can exchange key bits so you know they are secure because if
someone observed them, then they wouldn't be what they were.
Forget that. I'm going to allot all those details.
And that works. People have been doing this. Last I heard, the people at British Telecom
have a quantum key exchange going over 10 kilometers of fiber optic link. This really
does work. I was asked six months ago by a reporter covering this, does this matter?
Isn't this cool? And the answer to me is, of course, no. This is not something I need.
I'm not sitting here saying, oh, my cryptography isn't working well. I need quantum cryptography.
Here we're back at the mile-tall spike. Yes, you now can make the spike 10 miles tall.
Good for you. That's not going to solve my real problems.
So this is really cool science. I don't see a lot of practical applications.
Oh, down here.
I've been getting heavily into cluster computing. It's kind of become my bread and butter.
And you hear a lot of talk about cryptanalysis using it. But what about cryptography?
The question was about cluster distributed computing.
We're seeing a lot of good cryptanalysis happening. Distributed.net breaking DES and some of the RC6 challenges.
The question was, is there any useful cryptography to happen?
This is something I've been talking about with people.
You'd think there would be. Figuring out good S-boxes or good functions that are useful.
Just doing really big brute force searches for good things instead of for keys.
We haven't found anything yet that we can do that's useful.
When I do, we will tell you guys so everyone doing distributed computing can actually do it.
I'd like there to be, but I haven't really seen anything.
I should give you a tape.
That's not a crypto thing.
Somebody asked me about my new book.
How cool.
I have a new book coming out.
I have flyers for it over there and over there.
And I think they're also in the lobby by the bar.
After this is over, I'm going to be at the table. I'll have them there.
I have a new book coming out. It's either August or September.
I can't get my publisher to give me one answer.
So it's one of those two. It's already pre-sale on Amazon.
The book is called Secrets and Lies.
And it's a book really about the philosophy of security.
About a lot of the things I say up here.
What technologies can and can't do. How they work.
The limitations of cryptography and computer security and biometrics and PKI.
What the world looks like because of this and then how to survive anyway.
One of the things you learn when you go out into the real world is that the world is a pretty dangerous place.
Anybody could kill anybody else.
Yet we all do pretty well.
And looking at why this is so has lessons for computer security.
So I talk about that. It's actually a really cool book. I'm happy with it.
I hated it for a while. I liked it. Then I hated it. Now I like it again.
So I think it's a really good book and I'm happy to have written it.
Back there.
Another AES question. Someone close that door so I can hear this man.
Someone who's in the doorway should close the door.
Hi.
That's a good AES question that I ignored because it was dealt with.
A couple of years ago when I said that NIST would choose a winner.
The way they said they would choose approximately one winner.
The idea being they might choose more than one winner for some resilience methodology.
At the last AES workshop in New York, there was almost uniform denouncement of that idea.
That they should not choose multiple winners.
That the benefit of a standard is there are one of them.
And if we as cryptographers can't pick one standard, how can we expect implementers to?
So while NIST still has the prerogative to choose more than one winners,
I believe they will choose only one because they were told by everybody that we want just one.
Thanks. I ignored that because it was dealt with.
But people heard me last year. Don't know about the resolution.
White shirt over there.
Don't know.
I mean certainly an algorithm that you don't need a computer to use seems useful.
Not for me, but for people.
Solitaire itself has problems, so I don't recommend using that.
Yeah, I plan on updating it in my copious free time.
Now that I have the book finished, I might look at that again.
It does need a lot of work. It's a hard problem.
The problem of designing an algorithm that you can use without a computer that is secure against computers.
It's an interesting academic problem.
It seems to have a lot of interesting spycraft-like applications.
But, you know, I don't know.
So the moral here is don't use Solitaire, and I am going to update it sooner or later.
I will take the red hat.
Developments on encryption regulations being lifted, I haven't heard anything more than you've heard.
I don't have any good secret knowledge.
The questions I always get asked is, what does it mean?
The devil's in the details in those things.
Yeah, I just wrote what I heard of in the press.
I know nothing new.
And I'm really waiting until I hear some real data before I write it up again.
Sarah Flannery is basically the question.
This is the Irish 16 year old who invented a new way of doing public-key cryptography
and got a lot of press.
This is a good example of the media getting it completely wrong.
I mean, the story is basically true.
She did invent something.
It wasn't really that much of a big deal.
She seemed like a really smart person, and she's probably going to be a real good cryptographer eventually.
She seemed to understand that the media took it a lot of proportion.
It was not a major breakthrough.
It has since been broken.

I want to talk about attack models.
Because this is something I've been thinking about in the past few months.
It's something where I think cryptography has just gotten it completely wrong.
When you hear about cryptography, you hear about it in terms of the military eavesdropping model.
You have Alice and Bob.
Alice sends a message to Bob.
Eve is the eavesdropper.
So Alice encrypts the message so Eve can't hear it.
That's the way we've all learned about cryptography.
And we've taken that model into computer security.
Because when you buy computer security, computer security is pretty much always sold as a prophylactic.
Encryption prevents eavesdropping.
Firewalls prevent network access.
PKI prevents authentication.
Sorry, prevents impersonation.
Now, in the real world, not in the military world, you have a very different model of security.
Most security is not a prophylactic.
The reason we are secure is primarily because of detection and response.
So the entire legal system, the justice system, the police detecting a crime,
either in process or after the fact,
and there's some kind of response that includes prosecution and punishment.
Or burglar alarms working detection and response.
And in the real world, a much better way of doing security is detection and response, and not prevention.
Now, in the military, prevention is what you had.
You had a very different model. You couldn't detect and respond.
You're fighting, you worry about military powers, war, death, it's a big deal.
You need to have very strong preventive countermeasures.
And that's why the military model puts such a large emphasis on encryption and physical security.
And, you know, alarms, you never see alarms in warfare.
It doesn't make any sense.
You prevent. You prevent the enemy from doing whatever they want to do.
But in business, you don't think about preventing threats.
You think about managing risk.
And I believe this is a conceptual shift we're starting to see right now in computer security
because real people are now looking at the net.
The net was invented by geeks who thought about solving the problem technically.
Prevent the threat.
And then the military model fell into that.
So I believe we're going to see a lot more in the next few years of these sorts of detection and response.
Ways to deal with computer security that presuppose that your prevention countermeasures will fail.
This is sort of laser why I started the company.
But this is the meta thinking.
You have companies like Visa who say we have a couple of billion dollars of credit card fraud per year.
They could spend their time preventing the threat.
But instead they say, you know, it's only 12 basis points.
We're managing the risk just fine.
So you can have insecurity in business systems if you're making money.
If you're doing risk management properly, you're happy to be insecure.
E-Trade is a good example.
They have a very bad password authentication scheme.
It's very easy to hack.
But they're making lots of money.
They would rather have a low barrier to customer acquisition than high security.
Because it's more profitable for them.
And that's another.
That's the right way to manage risk.
Insurance is another deal.
The reason we have fire suppression equipment in this building is not because Alexis Park likes you all,
but because their insurance company demanded it.
Insurance tends to drive security in a lot of industries.
It's why you have burglar alarms in buildings.
It's why you have guards.
If you have a certain car alarm, you get a reduction in insurance rates.
And you're likely to see as computer security becomes more of a business tool and not just a geeky thing,
you'll see more of these risk management tools.
Because if you're a CEO, a secure computer is one you've insured.
You actually don't care.
If you can insure against the risk, you know exactly what your exposure is.
This computer initiative will cost me this much money.
And it's in some technical countermeasures, in some procedural countermeasures, in some insurance.
And then you're happy.
And that's the way you decide whether you deploy ATM machines,
whether you build a gold mine in the Congo.
That's where you make all of these decisions.
You make them based on risk management.
Because risk is a good thing.
In the military, risk was a bad thing.
But in business, risk is why you go into business.
It's the real parallel between the Internet and the American West.
The American West was a very dangerous place.
You had...
I have some books to give away.

You had justice by the fastest gun.

if I can get away with being less secure than you,
